<p>This guide is intended to outline the functional aspects of <b>The Marketplace</b> site. It should only be used to assist in the acquisition or resale of goods and services which you are lawfully permitted to purchase or engage in. Basically; don’t do anything naughty and if you do and Santa finds out, it’s on you. License: BSD – do whatever you want with it.</p>

<p>The following guide describes how to connect to and place your first order. Note: <b>The Marketplace</b> is on I2P which is slow compared to TOR, if you get timeouts, just refresh until it connects. The situation should improve as usage grows. This guide assumes you are configuring from scratch for a Windows system. The following software will be installed and used. You should download these pre-requisites to a folder on your hard-disk (E.g. C:\temp\tmpsetup\) before continuing.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://java.com/en/download/index.jsp">Java Virtual Machine</a>: Java software – prerequisite for I2P software to install</li>
<li><a href="http://www.mozilla.org/en-US/">Mozilla Firefox Browser</a>: Browser for accessing I2P network
<ul>
<li><a href="http://getfoxyproxy.org/">FoxyProxy Extension</a></li>
<li><a href="https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/quickjs/?src=api">QuickJS Extension</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="http://bitcoin.org/en/download">Bitcoin QT client 0.8.6+</a>: Default Bitcoin client – supports multi-signature transactions. You can also use Electrum (simple to swap in), but this guide only covers Bitcoin-QT</li>
<li><a href="http://gpg4win.org/download.html">GPG4Win 2.2.1</a>: Provides communication encryption</li>
<li><a href="http://www.i2p2.de/download.html">I2P 0.9.9 (or above) Windows Graphical Installer</a>: Provides access to the I2P network</li>
<li><a href="https://www.bitaddress.org/">Bit Address</a>: Used for generating the public/private keys you need for signing each order. You need to generate a new address for each order (see below for usage details)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.torproject.org/projects/torbrowser.html.en">TOR Browser Bundle</a>: Provides a more secure browser to use when using <b>TMP</b>.</li>
<li><a href="https://bitmessage.org/wiki/Main_Page">Bitmessage</a>: Provides a secure method for buyers and sellers to communicate outside of <b>TMP</b> – suggesd method for buyer-seller communication in section <i><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#whatif">Finalising transactions outside of The Marketplace</a></i> tutorial
<ul>
<li>About: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t_dTotavJZ8">Bitmessage</a> – Semi-technical video highlighting Bitmessage functionality. Not required, just for those interested.</li>
<li>Tutorial: <a href="https://axablends.com/merchants-accepting-bitcoin/bitmessage/how-to-setup-and-use-bitmessage/">Installing and Configuring Bitmessage</a> – Note: If you opt to connect over TOR, you may need to initially connect with Proxy of <b>None</b> otherwise the icon sits on red (unconnected) for hours. Once a successful connection has been established and the icon goes yellow, change the <b>Network Settings</b> to use the appropriate TOR proxy indicated in the tutorial link (127.0.0.1 Port 9150 or 127.0.0.1 Port 9050) and restart Bitmessage. The icon should be yellow or green and you’ll be connected over TOR.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><a href="https://tails.boum.org/download/">TAILS (Secure Linux)</a>: Provides a secure operating system to connect to <b>TMP</b>. Required as part of the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#installation-tails">Installation &amp; Configuration – For TAILS (Linux) with Electrum”</a> tutorial.</li>
<li><a href="https://electrum.org/download.html">Electrum – Lightweight Bitcoin Client</a>: Provides a simple, flexible Bitcoin Wallet that supports <b>The Marketplace</b> specific plugins to make seller order management easier. Required as part of the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#installation-tails">Installation &amp; Configuration – For TAILS (Linux) with Electrum</a> tutorial</li>
</ul>
<p><b>The Marketplace</b> is conceptually pretty different from the other markets out there. Other darknet markets are basically giant online wallets into which buyers transfer Bitcoins before they go shopping. Once the buyer has received their goods, they permit the darknet market to release the funds to the seller who must then withdraw them. Once of the biggest disadvantages of this approach is that both the seller and buyer need to trust the darknet market to not:</p>
<ul>
<li>collapse; or</li>
<li>walk away with all the money stored on the platform</li>
</ul>
<p>for the duration of the transaction. When either of these eventualities occur, it can be very expensive and frustrating for both buyers and sellers. <b>TMP</b> goes some way to addressing these concerns using what’s called <b>multi-signature transactions</b>. <b>Multi-signature transactions</b> allow all the parties involved in handling the money (so that’s the buyer who is paying, the seller who is to be paid for the goods and the darknet market that wants their fee for providing a website to do all the business on), to always retain some control over the money for the duration of the order.</p>
<h3>An Order Overview</h3>
<p>To accomplish this, the buyer, the seller and the darknet market agree on a single use Bitcoin Address (the <i>Bitcoin Deposit Address</i>) into which the buyer will deposit the Bitcoins necessary to pay for their order. This agreement is reached by the repurposing of Bitcoin Addresses (the ones you are normally familiar with using to deposit your Bitcoins too), to act as keys to the agreed <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. Each participant (that’s the buyer, the seller and the darknet market) generate a Bitcoin Address which they use as a key to the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. For anyone to move any of the Bitcoins out of the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, it requires that at least <b>two</b> of the key holders authorise it. Once a buyer has received their order, they will mark it as <b>Finalized</b> on the <b>TMP</b> website. <b>TMP</b> then effectively inserts their key (creates a transaction signed with their key) into the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> used for the order and asks the seller to do the same. Once the seller inserts their key (signs the transaction), the Bitcoins held in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> can be moved to the sellers nominated Bitcoin Address (E.g. a blockchain.info wallet, a BTC exchange etc) by broadcasting the signed transaction to the Bitcoin network. And that’s the magic. Unlike traditional darknet markets (Pandora, BlueSky etc), if <b>TMP</b> staff turned bad and wanted to steal the Bitcoins in a <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, they would also need either the buyer or the seller for every in-progress order to also sign off. If none of the parties agree, the Bitcoins will just sit in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> for eternity but it also means that a buyer and a seller can get together completely outside of <b>TMP</b> and release any Bitcoins stored in <b>Bitcoin Deposit Addresses</b> to which they both hold the keys.</p>
<h3>TMP Service Fees</h3>
<p>Those who have been paying attention may be wondering where <b>TMP</b> receives its fee in all this? Well, when <b>TMP</b> creates the transaction that both it and the seller will sign to release the Bitcoins held in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, the transaction contains two output Bitcoin Addresses. One is the sellers nominated Bitcoin Address and a second is a Bitcoin Address owned by <b>TMP</b> which is where their fee goes. The transaction that <b>TMP</b> creates and asks the seller to sign can be decoded and inspected to check the proportion of Bitcoins they’ve allocated to themselves from the Bitcoins held in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> before sign-off. Once the seller is happy, signs off and broadcasts the transaction to the Bitcoin network, everything is final and each party gets their share of the Bitcoins stored in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>.</p>
<h3>Declined Orders &amp; Order Cancellations</h3>
<p>When a buyer cancels an order that’s in progress or an order is declined by a seller (E.g. no stock etc), the process is the same as that of a seller signing off except that in this instance it is the buyer who signs-off to release the Bitcoins stored in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. <b>TMP</b> will ask the buyer to provide a Bitcoin Address they want their refund sent too, and then automatically create and sign the transaction (insert their key). The transaction is then passed to the buyer, who then signs off (inserts their key) and broadcasts the transaction to the Bitcoin network.</p>
<h3>Order Disputes</h3>
<p>Finally, in the unfortunate scenario where a buyer and a seller enter into a dispute (all toys out of the pram), <b>TMP</b> will propose a solution (For example; 50% of the Bitcoins held in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> to the buyer, and 50% to the seller). Provided at least the buyer *or* the seller agree to this, <b>TMP</b> will then sign the transaction and submit it to either the buyer or the seller for sign-off and broadcasting to the Bitcoin network. The Bitcoins will then be distributed as agreed.</p>
<h3>What if The Marketplace disappears?</h3>
<p>The beauty of <b>TMP</b> is that they are not required to release Bitcoins stored in <b>Bitcoin Deposit Addresses</b> provided the buyer and the seller can get in contact with each other and agree on a transaction. It may therefore be a good idea for buyers and sellers participating in regular or large transactions to provide alternative contact details for each other so that in the event of a service outage, any outstanding orders can be finalized and the Bitcoins released. <b>Note:</b> In this instance either the buyer or the seller would need to create and sign a transaction which the opposite party (buyer or seller) would also need to sign-off on. Either party could then broadcast the signed transaction to the Bitcoin network. Creating a raw transaction to finalize without <b>TMP</b> is covered in this section of the guide: <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#whatif">Finalising transactions outside of The Marketplace</a>. You may also (if you are technically minded) want to read up on raw transactions and that information can be found here: <a href="https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Raw_Transactions">Raw Transactions</a>.</p>
<h2 id="installation-win">For Windows</h2>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol>
<li>Double click the I2P software installer (i2pinstall_0.9.9_windows.exe)</li>
<li>Press <b>[Next]</b> until you reach the pack installation choice window</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/11.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3214" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/11.png" alt="1" width="590" height="356" /> </a></li>
<li>The default option <b>Base</b> will be checked, but you also have the option of installing I2P as a <b>Windows Service</b>. This means it will automatically run in the background whenever you start your computer and you will always be participating in the I2P network. If you intend to be a frequent user, you may wish to consider this option for two reasons:
<ul>
<li>A) Everyone who uses I2P provides routing services and bandwidth for everyone else – e.g. in the same was as you upload a torrent when you’re not downloading to help others, if you are always connected to I2P you help make the network faster for everyone else.</li>
<li>B) Plausible deniability. If you are always connected to I2P, regardless of whether you are using it, your traffic cannot be so easily categorised as unique by malicious entities. For example, in the recent <a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/failing-grade-alleged-harvard-bomb-hoaxer-needed-more-tor-cover-2D11767028">Harvard Bombscare</a> the perpetrator was caught because Law Enforcement worked out how many unique users were on the TOR network at the time, and paid each one of them a visit. The perpetrator had only logged on to TOR briefly during the period identified by LE, and therefore stuck a huge red flag on himself. If you are always connected to I2P, it would be significantly more difficult to accuse you of using it for less than legal purposes…assuming you did, which of course you wouldn’t.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Press <b>[Next]</b> through all the remaining steps and <b>[Done]</b> once the software has installed <a href="/imgs/2014/01/22.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3225" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/22.png" alt="2" width="590" height="356" /> </a></li>
<li>If you have opted to install I2P as a <b>Windows Service</b> you will stop the service for the purposes of this tutorial. This ensures you can check for errors. If you have <b>not</b> opted to install as a <b>Windows Service</b>, skip to the next step.
<ul>
<li>A) <b>Start</b>-&gt;<b>Run</b>-&gt;type: <b>services.msc</b> and press <b>[Enter]</b></li>
<li>B) Scroll down until you find <b>I2P Service</b></li>
<li>C) Right click and select <b>Stop</b></li>
<li>D) Close the Services window</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Click <b>Start</b> and navigate to <b>I2P</b> shortcuts menu and click <b>Start I2P (restartable)</b>. The I2P software will now start.</li>
<li>You will be presented with the I2P command box:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/3.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3226" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/31.png" alt="3" width="674" height="340" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>followed shortly by your default browser opening with the I2P web interface:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/41.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3238" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/41.png" alt="4" width="800" height="800" /> </a></p>
<p>7-At this point it takes I2P several minutes to initialise and find the necessary connections to other participants in the network. Click the I2P logo in the top left hand corner (market in red in the screenshot below) to change the management bar to reflect the details of your I2P connection. You may need to click twice before the full management view is visible.</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/51.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3239" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/51.png" alt="5" width="206" height="907" /> </a></p>
<p>Once the management bar is visible look down and once you see <b>Network: OK</b> (in the green box in the above screenshot), you are connected to the I2P network. The lower box that says “Rejecting tunnels: starting up” will eventually change to “Accepting tunnels”. You can optionally wait for this stage if you want to ensure you are a full participant in the I2P network. It can take about 30 minutes. 8. Now that I2P has loaded, you need to configure your browser in order to access the marketplace. As indicated in the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#prerequisites">pre-requisites</a>, we’ll be using <b>Mozilla Firefox</b>. The next stage is therefore to install <b>Mozilla Firefox</b> and the <b>QuickJS</b> and <b>FoxyProxy</b> extensions. 9. Once you have installed <b>Mozilla Firefox</b> and the extensions, you should see two new icons in the browser: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/61.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3240" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/61.png" alt="6" width="1011" height="80" /> </a> 10. Click the <b>FoxyProxy</b> icon to bring up the configuration window: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/7.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3242" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/71.png" alt="7" width="721" height="465" /> </a></p>
<p>Ensure the window looks like the screenshot above and select <b>Add New Proxy</b> from the menu on the left side. When the <b>Proxy Settings</b> window is displayed, choose the <b>Proxy Details</b> tab and enter <b>127.0.0.1</b> in the <b>Host or IP Address</b> box and <b>4444</b> in the <b>Port</b> box: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/8.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3243" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/8.png" alt="8" width="820" height="647" /> </a></p>
<p>Click the <b>URL Patterns</b> tab and click <b>Add New Pattern</b>. Choose a <b>Pattern Name</b> of <b>I2P</b> and in the <b>URL pattern</b> box enter <b>*.i2p*</b>. Click <b>[OK]</b>. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/9.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3244" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/9.png" alt="9" width="489" height="315" /> </a></p>
<p>Click <b>[OK]</b> to return to the configuration window. It should now look like this: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/10.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3245" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/10.png" alt="10" width="721" height="465" /> </a></p>
<p>Click <b>[Close]</b>.</p>
<ol>
<li>You are now configured to connect your <b>Mozilla Firefox</b> browser to I2P. The penultimate stage is to check that JavaScript is disabled. The <b>QuickJS</b> icon should be clicked until it represents a broken wheel (hovering over will show that this is JavaScript disabled mode):</li>
<li>In the address bar of <b>Mozilla Firefox</b> enter <b>http://themarketplace.i2p</b> – The I2P network will then wander off to try and route your connection. It is likely that you will receive a window saying <b>Warning Eepsite Not Found in Addressbook</b>. When this appears, click the <b>stats.i2p jump service</b> link.</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/11.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3247" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/111.png" alt="11" width="1018" height="870" /> </a> When this returns, you should receive a <b>Success</b> window like the one below. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/12.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3248" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/121.png" alt="12" width="1018" height="870" /> </a> You will be automatically directed to save the address to your router configuration (see screenshot below), when this window displays choose <b>Save themarketplace.i2p to router address book and continue to eepsite</b>. It may take several attempts to get this process to happen. You only need to do this once though, when you navigate to <b>http://themarketplace.i2p</b> in future, it should route you directly. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/13.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3249" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/141.png" alt="14" width="1006" height="520" /> </a> Finally, you will reach your goal – <b>The Market Place</b>…</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/14.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3250" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/151.png" alt="15" width="673" height="651" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Select the <b>[Register]</b> button to begin the registration process. As part of this process you will need to supply a PGP encryption key. This ensures that all correspondence between you and any other vendors of the site is encrypted. If you have already got a PGP public key, you can paste it in here and skip past the following steps, if not – you need to install the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#prerequisites">GPG4Win 2.2.1</a> package listed in the prerequisites and follow the instructions below to create your key.</li>
<li>Install the GPG4Win 2.2.1 package – as part of this process <b>ensure you check the box to install GPA</b>, and once installed select <b>Start</b>-&gt;<b>GPA</b> icon from the start menu. This will launch the GNU Privacy Assistant which you will use to encrypt and decrypt any communications and generate your initial PGP public key.</li>
<li>When GPA starts for the first time it will ask you if you wish to <b>Generate a Key</b> or <b>Do it Later</b>. Choose <b>Do it Later</b> and navigate to <b>Keys</b> menu and choose <b>New key…</b>.</li>
<li>When the <b>Generate key</b> wizard displays, enter your username that you intend to use on The Marketplace:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/15.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3251" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/16.png" alt="16" width="692" height="630" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Click <b>[Forward]</b> and enter a fake email address of {THE-MARKETPLACE-USERNAME}@themarketplace.i2p, E.g. <b><a class="__cf_email__" href="http://www.cloudflare.com/email-protection" data-cfemail="c6b2abb6b2a3b5b2a7a5a5a9b3a8b286b2aea3aba7b4ada3b2b6aaa7a5a3e8aff4b6">[email protected]</a><script type="text/javascript">// <![CDATA[
    (function(){try{var s,a,i,j,r,c,l,b=document.getElementsByTagName("script");l=b[b.length-1].previousSibling;a=l.getAttribute('data-cfemail');if(a){s='';r=parseInt(a.substr(0,2),16);for(j=2;a.length-j;j+=2){c=parseInt(a.substr(j,2),16)^r;s+=String.fromCharCode(c);}s=document.createTextNode(s);l.parentNode.replaceChild(s,l);}}catch(e){}})();
    // ]]&gt;</script></b>. Click <b>[Forward]</b>.</li>
<li>At this stage you can optionally create a backup of your key. This is recommended and you should store the backup on a secure USB stick that only you have access to. This means if you encounter a hardware failure or other problem, you can always decrypt communications for your The Marketplace account, especially important if you’re a vendor. Click <b>[Forward]</b></li>
<li>Finally, you will be prompted for a passphrase. Ensure its a memorable, strong password – you will need to use it every-time you want to decrypt a communication.</li>
<li>You’ve now created the keys you need for your <b>The Marketplace</b> registration, now to export the keys. Right click your new key and select <b>Export Keys…</b> from the menu</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/16.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3253" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/17.png" alt="16" width="696" height="638" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>You will be prompted to save the public portion of your key (this is the bit you can circulate to anyone so they can encrypt communications for you) to a file. Choose a location on your hard disk E.g. c:\temp\tmp\mypubkey.txt</li>
<li>Start <b>Notepad</b> (or your favourite text editor) and open the newly saved public key file. Copy the text content from the file into the <b>The Marketplace</b> registration form and complete the registration process.</li>
<li id="checkout">You will now be logged in. Click the <b>Products</b> link from the menu bar and shop for some legal, medicinal remedies. Once you’ve chosen, lets cover how you actually pay for your item… Navigate to your cart and click the <b>[Checkout]</b> button</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/17.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3254" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/18.png" alt="18" width="745" height="446" /> </a></p>
<p>Your order will now be created and require payment. <b>The Marketplace</b> is unique in that it requires multi-signature transactions, which basically means that you, the vendor and TMP Staff all have keys to your transaction, <b>but</b> in order for any one person to claim it, two of you have to agree. This ensures that the TMP staff can’t walk away with your (or the vendors) money. It would require either collusion between the TMP staff and the vendor, or yourself – either way, the potential damage is limited. On the screen under <b>Order requires payment</b> choose <b>Please click here to create the escrow address</b> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/18.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3255" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/19.png" alt="18" width="914" height="349" /> </a></p>
<p>You will now be requested to enter the <b>Public Key</b> that will be used to create the new wallet to which you will send funds. The terminology says “wallet”, but what it actually means is: “create a new Bitcoin Deposit Address that is unique to this order and to which you will pay your Bitcoins”. Each order will involve creating a different Bitcoin Address, unique to that order into which you will deposit your cash to pay for your order. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/19.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3256" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/20.png" alt="19" width="905" height="322" /> </a></p>
<p>When you are presented with the <b>Create escrow address</b> window, you need to create a Public Key which is used – along with the vendor and TMP Staff’s public keys – to create a unique Bitcoin Address into which you will deposit your money to pay for your goods. This sounds confusing, but what you are basically doing is providing your part of the key in this multi-signature transaction. So, to do this you need to generate a public key. Navigate to <a href="https://www.bitaddress.org/">https://www.bitaddress.org/</a> to generate a new Bitcoin Address (<b>NOTE:</b> This Bitcoin Address is nothing to do with your order, it’s just an easy way to generate a public and private key. So don’t accidentally deposit funds to it). Once you generated your Bitcoin Address, it should look something like this: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/20.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3257" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/211.png" alt="20" width="1041" height="334" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li id="buyerkey">The only bit you are interested in is the <b>Private Key</b>. Copy the <b>Private key</b> value into a text file somewhere and keep it safe <b>DONT LOSE IT</b>. You will need it to authorise or finalise the order or in the case of a dispute.</li>
<li>Now you need to get the Public Key. On <a href="https://www.bitaddress.org/">https://www.bitaddress.org/</a> copy the Private Key to your clipboard and click the <b>Wallet Details</b> tab. Here, enter the Private Key and click the <b>[View Details]</b> button.</li>
<li>Highlight the <b>Public Key (130 characters [0-9A-F]):</b> value and copy it to your clipboard.</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/21.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3258" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/221.png" alt="21" width="1016" height="501" /> </a>Return to <b>The Marketplace</b> and paste this into the <b>Public key (SEC)</b> box and click <b>[Create escrow address]</b> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/22.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3259" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/23.png" alt="22" width="931" height="311" /> </a> Your single use Bitcoin Deposit Address will now be created: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/23.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3260" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/24.png" alt="23" width="889" height="458" /> </a></p>
<p>Send the exact amount required to this address using the Bitcoin QT client (or Electrum if you are using it) and record the transaction ID. To do this, open Bitcoin-QT and click the <b>[Send]</b> button. Copy the details carefully from <b>The Marketplace</b> order window and send the required funds. You can use the <b>Label:</b> field if you are using Bicoin-QT to record the Private Key you generated in Step 24 for your order (it’s only visible to you). This makes it easier to find the key you need in the event of a refund you need to claim. The format <b>{FRIENDLY-LABEL}</b> – PRIV KEY: <b>{REPURPOSED-BTC-ADDRESS-PRIVATE-KEY}</b> ADDRESS: <b>{REPURPOSED-BTC-ADDRESS}</b> works well.</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/24.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3261" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/25.png" alt="24" width="819" height="224" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Once the funds have been sent, you need to retrieve the transaction id so that <b>The Marketplace</b> knows that you’ve paid. In Bitcoin-QT, click the <b>[Transactions]</b> button, simply highlight the recent transaction you’ve just made, right click and select <b>Copy transaction id</b>. The transaction will be copied to your clipboard.</li>
<li>Return to <b>The Marketplace</b> and paste the transaction ID into the box and click <b>[Record transaction]</b>. <b>Note:</b> Ensure you strip off the “-000″ that Bitcoin-QT appends so for example: <b>8512e2728ca2153be0809d1252ecd8dfc6833a53fbfe1f8ba6f64ae19eaed663-000</b> you remove the <b>-000</b> so it’s just <b>8512e2728ca2153be0809d1252ecd8dfc6833a53fbfe1f8ba6f64ae19eaed663</b> before clicking <b>[Record transaction]</b>.</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/25.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3263" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/26.png" alt="25" width="857" height="194" /> </a><b></b></p>
<p><b>The Marketplace</b> will now take over and monitor the transaction. Once it reaches the required number of confirmations, it will be forwarded to the vendor for processing. Note: You can cancel the transaction even after it has been paid but before it has been passed to the vendor. For more information on refunds and how to claim one, see the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#refunds">Refunds</a> section. But we’re not done quite yet! Finally, you need to set your address so the vendor knows when to send your order. Click the <b>[Set Address]</b> button.</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/26.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3265" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/27.png" alt="26" width="888" height="122" /> </a></p>
<p><b></b>You now need to encrypt your delivery address, and send it to the vendor. In the top right hand of the screen, click the <b>[View vendors PGP Key]</b> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/27.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3266" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/28.png" alt="27" width="898" height="389" /> </a></p>
<p>A new window will open and inside will be the vendors PGP public key, which you use if you want to send them any correspondence. Copy the text contents of this window to your clipboard, open Notepad (or your favourite text editor), paste it in and save the file to somewhere on your hard-disk, E.g. C:\temp\tmp\myvendorpubkey.txt</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/28.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3267" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/29.png" alt="28" width="557" height="612" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>You can close the browser tab once you’ve saved the key. Just keep the tab that requires your delivery address open.</li>
<li>Now to import the vendors key into GPA. Click <b>Start</b>-&gt;<b>GPA</b> icon from your start-menu to start <b>GNU Privacy Assistant</b>.</li>
<li>Click the <b>[Import]</b> button on the toolbar, and navigate to where you saved the vendors public key you just copied from your browser. The key will be imported and you should see it listed:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/29.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3268" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/30.png" alt="29" width="696" height="638" /> </a></p>
<p>Each vendor will have their own key. This ensures that if <b>The Marketplace</b> is ever breached, any communications intercepted between vendors and buyers are effectively unreadable. Click the <b>Clipboard</b> button. The <b>GNU Privacy Assistant – Clipboard</b> is where you encrypt any communications to vendors and decrypt any communications in messages sent to you. Enter your delivery address in the window <a href="/imgs/2014/01/30.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3269" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/311.png" alt="30" width="656" height="518" /> </a></p>
<p>Once you have entered it, click the <b>[Encrypt]</b> button and choose the vendors key. The text will be replaced by the encrypted version which can only be decrypted by the intended recipient (your vendor in this case).</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/31.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3270" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/32.png" alt="31" width="656" height="518" /> </a></p>
<p>Copy this encrypted text to your clipboard and paste it into <b>The Marketplace</b> <b>Update address</b> window and click <b>[Submit]</b>. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/32.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3271" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/33.png" alt="32" width="745" height="393" /> </a></p>
<p>That’s it, your order is now with the vendor. In due course you should receive your order. When you do, you need to login to the site to finalize: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/33.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3272" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/34.png" alt="33" width="969" height="395" /> </a></p>
<p>You will now be prompted to leave a review (which you should do for the benefit of other potential customers) and the order life-cycle is complete. If you were unfortunate enough not to receive your order, or have another issue with the buyer, you can open a <b>Dispute</b>. This is covered elsewhere in this guide.</p>
<p>Refunds are the mechanism used by <b>TMP</b> to return Bitcoins to a buyer who has:</p>
<ul>
<li>paid for an order but decided to cancel it; or</li>
<li>had a paid order cancelled by a seller</li>
</ul>
<p>For any order that has been paid but that has not been Approved by the seller, the buyer will be able to claim a refund. Lets cover the process step-by-step from the buyers perspective. <b>NOTE:</b> If you are experimenting to understand the refund process, you will need to use some Bitcoins (the process isn’t risk free). If you are a seller, you can create and purchase one of your own products (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#selling">Selling</a> for more information). If you are just an average, curious buyer – find a suitable cheap product from a listed vendor and just <b>[Cancel]</b> the transaction as soon as you have paid for it. Create an order on <b>TMP</b> by following <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p/#checkout">Steps 21 to 35 inclusive</a> of the buyers guide. Immediately after making payment and recording the transaction ID, your order screen should look something like this: You will now be prompted to leave a review (which you should do for the benefit of other potential customers) and the order life-cycle is complete. If you were unfortunate enough not to receive your order, or have another issue with the buyer, you can open a <b>Dispute</b>. This is covered elsewhere in this guide.</p>
<h2 id="installation-tails">For TAILS (Linux) With Electrum</h2>
<p>This section covers the setup of the TAILS Secure Linux distribution along with installing the Electrum Bitcoin wallet and the <b>TMP</b> Electrum plugin.<br />
    We&#8217;ll also be covering how to use some of the options<br />
    provided by the <b>TMP</b> Electrum plugin, including; bulk seller key generation to create a large number of order keys quickly, creating a key (as a buyer) for Refunds and importing transactions (Refunds or Payment Retrival) from<br />
<b>TMP</b> for signing (inserting <i>your</i> key as either the buyer or the seller) and broadcast to the Bitcoin network.</p>
<p>One of the advantages of using TAILS is that it allows you to segregate your darknet activities from your main operating system (OS), however by design TAILS is forgetful. That means that every-time you reboot it, it&#8217;s as if<br />
    you never used it. Any data that you created (PGP keys, wallets, installed applications etc) during your previous use of TAILS is lost. To remedy this, the TAILS OS provides the ability to configure <i>persistent storage</i>. Persistent storage<br />
    reserves a bit of space on your USB or SD Card to allow configuration files and data to carry over between each reboot. In order to configure persistence, you need to do it from <b>within</b> the TAILS operating system.</p>
<p>Before we begin, you will need a blank DVD and a USB or SD Card available. You will use the DVD to get the TAILS running and then you will use the USB or SD Card to create a new installation of TAILS that has persistent storage enabled.<br />
    This is all covered in detail below.</p>
<p><b>Note:</b> If you are running virtualisation software such as <a href="http://www.vmware.com/uk/products/workstation/">VMWare Workstation (Windows)</a>, <a href="http://www.vmware.com/uk/products/fusion/">VMWare Fusion (Mac)</a> or <a href="https://www.virtualbox.org/">Virtualbox</a> on your computer, you can use this<br />
    in place of the blank DVD to get TAILS initially started. You can also opt to use a <b>second</b> USB stick or SD Card in place of the DVD &#8211; installation instructions are provided here: <a href="https://tails.boum.org/doc/first_steps/installation/manual/index.en.html">Manually installing TAILS onto a USB Stick or SD card</a>.</p>
<p>Let&#8217;s begin&#8230;</p>
<ol>
<ol>
<li id="tails-s1">Download the TAILS iso image from the TAILS website: <a href="https://tails.boum.org/download/#index2h1">https://tails.boum.org/download/#index2h1</a> and save it somewhere on your hard-disk (E.g. c:\temp\tails-i386-0.22.iso)</li>
<li>Insert the blank DVD, locate the TAILS iso image (E.g. c:\temp\tails-i386-0.22.iso) and burn it to your DVD. You should use a competent burning program for this task such as <a href="http://www.imgburn.com/index.php?act=download">ImgBurn</a>.</li>
<li>Reboot your computer with the freshly cooked DVD in your DVD drive to start TAILS. Remember; you will need to configure your PC to boot from the DVD drive if it doesn&#8217;t automatically &#8211; you can find these options in the BIOS (usually a frantic tapping of the <b>[F12]</b> or <b>[DEL]</b> keys when you first switch on your computer).</li>
<li id="tails-s4">TAILS should boot and you will be presented with a screen shown below:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3273" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/35.png" alt="34" width="768" height="576" />Choose click <b>[Forward]</b></li>
<li>Now Tails will load and you can run the installer to install Tails to your USB flash drive. Be warned that many modern Apple computers will not boot Tails from USB without some special tricks.</li>
<li>The next step is to create a copy of TAILS with persistent storage enabled. Remember; TAILS forgets everything between reboots, so you need the ability to persist important data so you don&#8217;t have to re-enter it every-time.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/opentailsinstaller.png" alt="" />When the <b>Tails installer</b> window displays, insert your USB stick or SD Card into your PC and choose <b>[Clone] &amp; Install</b></li>
</ol>
</ol>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/tailsinstallerinitialscreen.png" alt="" /></p>
<ol>
<ol>
<li>Your USB Drive or SD Card should be listed in the drop-down box. If you have multiple USB devices or SD Cards connected, select the correct one and click <b>[Install Tails]</b>. Remember; you will lose everything on the USB stick or SD Card, so if you are in any doubt which USB or SD Card is the correct one,<br />
    remove all except the one you are going to use to install TAILS <i>with persistent storage</i> onto.<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-3281" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/40-300x290.png" alt="39" width="300" height="290" /></li>
</ol>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li>When the process is finished, you should receive a confirmation dialog. Your portable, persistent storage-able (but not enabled yet) TAILS installation is now ready.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/40.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3282" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/411-300x262.png" alt="40" width="300" height="262" /><br />
</a>Reboot the system using the leaving the USB stick or SD card in place. If your PC is not set to boot from an SD Card or USB stick, you will need to enter the BIOS as you did in <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#tails-s1">Step 1</a>. Refer to your motherboard manufacturers guide if you are in any doubt about how to do this.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/reboottails.png" alt="" /></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li>Once your PC has restarted, you want to this time select &#8216;Yes&#8217; for additional options and enter a root password. Normally you do not want root enabled, but we will need it to set up some persistence settings. We now need to create the persistent storage volume. This tells TAILS what you want to allow to persist between reboots and that you want to reserve a bit of space on the USB stick or SD card to store all this information.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Open the &#8216;Configure persistent volume&#8217; in the Application menu. Remember; it&#8217;s protecting the evidence (not that you&#8217;ve anything to hide&#8230;) so don&#8217;t pick a password you&#8217;ve used anywhere else (Facebook, Gmail etc), make it strong and <b>don&#8217;t forget it!</b> (There is no recovery if you do).</p>
<p><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3285" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/44.png" alt="43" width="531" height="592" /></p>
<p>When you&#8217;ve chosen, click the <b>[Create]</b> button.</p>
<ul>
<li>You want to keep as little as possible around, but you want at least &#8216;Personal Data&#8217;, GnuPG, and Dotfiles. Browser bookmarks may be good if you&#8217;re not good at remembering, but you can store important websites in another way that&#8217;s a bit more safe.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/setuppersist1.png" alt="" /><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/setuppersist2.png" alt="" />
<p>Click the <b>[Save]</b> button to commit your changes.</li>
<li>Now we are going to make i2p a little quicker for us, since we will be using it to access the site. There should be a i2p preset in the prior screens in a future version of Tails, but for now we will have to manually do it. Go to <b>Applications</b> -&gt; <b>Accessories</b> -&gt; <b>Root Terminal</b> and enter the admin password when prompted. Then run the following to edit the persistence configuration files, remeber to hit Ctrl-O to save the changes to your file when you&#8217;ve added the extra line at the end.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/addi2ppersist.png" alt="" /><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/addi2ppersist2.png" alt="" /></li>
<li>Your persisted volume is now configured, but not yet enabled. You need to reboot to make the changes permanent. Select <b>System</b>-&gt;<b>Administration</b>-&gt;<b>Reboot</b> to restart.</li>
<li id="tails-s14">When TAILS has restarted, you&#8217;ll be presented with a different login screen to the one you&#8217;re used to:<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3287" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/46.png" alt="45" width="387" height="316" />Under <i>Use persistence?</i> choose <b>[Yes]</b> and in the <b>Passphrase</b> box, enter the password to your persist volume that you entered in <b>Step 11</b>. Leave the <b>Read-Only?</b> box <b>unchecked</b>. Do not click on &#8216;More options&#8217;. You will not need to enable it except for rare situations.</li>
<li id="tails-s16">Now we want to start installing some sorftware for use with The Marketplace. Before we start on this, we want to start up the I2P router so that it has time to get itself running before we actually need to access the any eepSites.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/Screenshotopeni2p.png" alt="" />Ignore the router window or minimize it when it opens up. Now we will want to open Iceweasel, (it&#8217;s the globe icon right next to <b>System</b>, and go to <a> and get the latest version of Electrum. Select the &#8216;Open with Archive Manager&#8217; option so that you can extract it to the correct directory when it&#8217;s done.</a>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/downloadelectrum.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/downloadelectrum2.png" alt="" /></li>
<li><a><br />
    Now we want to extract Electrum into the persistence folder. Right click on the Electrum directory in the Archive Manager and choose to extract it into the &#8216;Peristence&#8217; Folder.</a><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/extractelectrum1.png" alt="" /><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/extractelectrum2.png" alt="" /></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li>We want to set up scripts to start up Electrum correctly. We want to make sure it always connects to the correct servers and that we keep our escrow address keeps seperate from our cash handling keys. You can modify the &#8216;electrum.desktop&#8217; file to save a script to run Electrum for monies.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/realcashwalletconfig.png" alt="" /><br />
    Modify the file silghtly again and save as a newfile, one for a wallet that onlydoes key storage and signing for you.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/escrowwalletconfig.png" alt="" /></li>
<li>Now we install the plugin file. In order to download it, first you&#8217;ll heve to register for for the forums. You want to at the very least use no password twice. Luckliy Tails comes with a password manager built in.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/openkeeppassx.png" alt="" />Create a new password database. Be sure to pick a very strong password to use to keep all your passwords in. If you lose this, you&#8217;ll likely not ever be able toget back into your accounts.
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/createkeepassx.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/newkeepassxpassword.png" alt="" /></li>
<li>New lets set up some passwords for our stuff. Add a new entry and pick a new user name that&#8217;s not connected to any of your lawful activities,<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/newentry.png" alt="" />Then use the password generator to make a secure password.
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/Screenshot-i2pforums1.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/Screenshot-Password_Generator.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/completednewprofile.png" alt="" /></p>
<p>Now you have to <b>save your password database</b>. It&#8217;s important you save your password database after every new password entry you create in the password vault.</p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/saveyourdatas.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/savedatas2.png" alt="" /></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li><a><br />
    By now I2P should&#8217;ve had time to get ready for use. Disable Javacript on your browser, then head over to </a><a href="http://themarketplace.i2p/">http://themarketplace.i2p</a>.<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/disablejs.png" alt="" />You are likely going to get an error message becasue your router doesn&#8217;t know how to get to the market yet. Pick the stats.i2p jump service link, then select the open to save the domain to the counter and continue on.</p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/addmarketplacetorouter1.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/addmarketplacetobook2.png" alt="" /></p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/loginscreen.png" alt="" /></p>
<p>We will go to the forum first to pick up the add-on. Fill out the registration info in the registration link. Since you don&#8217;t know (or care) whan gibberish your password is, you can easy right click on the account in KeePassX to copy the password into the clipboard so you can paste it in the correct field. Then navigate to the plugin thread and download the latest copy.</p>
<p><img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/saveplugin.png" alt="" /></p>

<p>You now want to run each one of the startup scripts to create two wallets. Remember, if you need a password, be sure to generate a fresh one in KeePassX and <b>save</b> the password after creation.</p>
