Then run this command<img src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/tmpguide/saveelectrumprefs.png" alt="" /></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ul>
<li>Finally, to round of this exercise, lets shutdown and check that all the hard work has been persisted. Now you want to exit electrum and reinter it without the admin password or additional options being enabled.</li>
<li>If everything has persisted correctly, Electrum will now start synchronizing and you&#8217;ll find your Bitcoin Addresses (order keys / transactions etc) will have been preserved.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Additional information on PGP key management and detail on the <b>TMP</b> plugin will follow in subsequent versions of this guide (hopefully).</p>
<p>Final note: there is probably a great deal more integration and optimization that can be done and you should not interpret this as the defacto guide to best practice &#8211; the author is not an expert. It should get you up and running<br />
    with a degree of security and once you are happy, you can begin experimenting with the additional functionality afforded by TAILS.</p>
<p>Refunds are the mechanism used by <b>TMP</b> to return Bitcoins to a buyer who has:</p>
<ul>
<li>paid for an order but decided to cancel it; or</li>
<li>had a paid order cancelled by a seller</li>
</ul>
<p>For any order that has been paid but that has not been Approved by the seller, the buyer will be able to claim a refund. Lets cover the process step-by-step from the buyers perspective. <b>NOTE:</b> If you are experimenting to understand the refund process, you will need to use some Bitcoins (the process isn’t risk free). If you are a seller, you can create and purchase one of your own products (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling">Selling</a> for more information). If you are just an average, curious buyer – find a suitable cheap product from a listed vendor and just <b>[Cancel]</b> the transaction as soon as you have paid for it. Create an order on <b>TMP</b> by following <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#checkout">Steps 21 to 35 inclusive</a> of the buyers guide. Immediately after making payment and recording the transaction ID, your order screen should look something like this: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/711.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3315" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/711.png" alt="71" width="968" height="493" /> </a></p>
<p>It does not matter if your payment has received any confirmations – just click the <b>[Cancel order]</b> button. The order will vanish from your list (This can be slightly confusing since <b>TMP</b> does not at the time of writing provide any feedback to you as a buyer, but don’t worry – your refund exists). From the menu on the left-hand side under the <b>Orders</b> heading, click the <b>[Refunds]</b> link to bring up the Refunds Window: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/72.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3316" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/72.png" alt="72" width="1350" height="358" /> </a> When the window displays, you will see a list of all the <b>Refunds</b> that are available for you to claim. <b>Remember: One <i>paid</i> cancelled or declined order = one refund.</b> In the <b>Withdraw to wallet</b> field, enter the Bitcoin Address you want your refund sent to and click the <b>[Sign]</b> button. This can be any Bitcoin Address – for example an exchange deposit address, a blockchain.info wallet address, a paper wallet address etc. Wherever you like, just make sure you own it. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/73.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3317" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/73.png" alt="73" width="981" height="239" /> </a> The <b>Transaction</b> window will now be displayed – DONT PANIC! It looks complicated, but its pretty straightforward once you get the hang of it. Remember the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#concepts">Concepts</a>? <b>TMP</b> has taken your requested refund Bitcoin Address and created a signed transaction (inserted their key) into the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> that your Bitcoins are currently sitting in. So, in order for those Bitcoins to be released to you, you – as the buyer – also need to sign on the dotted line (insert your key). Once you’ve signed off, you can broadcast the transaction to the Bitcoin network and the Bitcoins will wing their way to your nominated Bitcoin Address. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/74.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3318" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/74.png" alt="74" width="975" height="733" /> </a></p>
<p>In the subsequent steps, you’ll be running two commands:</p>
<ul>
<li><b>signrawtransaction</b>: Allows you to sign-off the transaction (inserts your key into the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>)</li>
<li><b>sendrawtransaction</b>: Broadcasts the signed transaction to the Bitcoin Network. Remember: Bitcoin is a big distributed ledger, it has to <i>know</i> about the transaction or it didn’t happen</li>
</ul>
<p>To run these commands you will need to have Bitcoin-QT installed and connected to the internet. You will also need the Private Key from your repurposed Bitcoin Address that you stored when you created your order (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#buyerkey">Steps 24-to-27 in the Buyers Guide</a>). Before we get to the Bitcoin-QT commands, we’re going to decode and check the transaction on <a href="https://blockchain.info/decode-tx">https://blockchain.info/decode-tx</a>. This (and the following step) are purely optional stages, but just lets you feel comfortable that your refund is going to go to the Bitcoin Address you have nominated. Highlight the text between the quotes as demonstrated in the screenshot below, and copy it to your clipboard: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/75.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3319" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/75.png" alt="75" width="977" height="735" /> </a></p>
<p>Navigate to <a href="https://blockchain.info/decode-tx">https://blockchain.info/decode-tx</a> inside the TOR browser (to protect your privacy) and paste the text in and click the <b>[Submit Transaction]</b>. The result should be something like that shown below: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/76.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3320" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/76.png" alt="76" width="1206" height="541" /> </a> Now that you’re happy with the proposed refund, you want to sign it off and get back the Bitcoins. Open Bitcoin-QT, go to <b>Menu</b>-&gt;<b>Debug Window</b> and click the <b>Console</b> tab. The view should look like this:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/77.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3321" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/77.png" alt="77" width="756" height="488" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>You now need to create the <b>signrawtransaction</b> command from the transaction text provided by <b>TMP</b> and the Private Key from the repurposed Bitcoin Address. Mercifully, there are some quick and dirty formatting tools to do most of the work for you at the base of this guide under the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransaction-refundtools">Transaction String Formatting – Refunds</a> heading. There are two stages:
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrefund-stage1">Stage 1. Generate *REFUND* DOS bitcoind.exe or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible signrawtransaction command</a>; and</li>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrefund-stage2">Stage 2. Generate *REFUND* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible sendrawtransaction command</a></li>
</ul>
<p>We’re going to use these tools, click the link to <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrefund-stage1">Stage 1</a> above, and paste the requested values into the boxes (The Private Key and the <b>TMP</b> signed transaction text). A helpful screenshot tells you what text you need to copy from the <b>TMP</b> window. Once you’ve done this, click the <b>[Format Refund Transaction]</b> button and copy the blue result text that appears below to your clipboard.</li>
<li>Return to the Bitcoin-QT debug window and paste all the text in and press <b>[Enter]</b>.</li>
<li>You should receive a result something like this in the black text:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/78.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3322" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/78.png" alt="78" width="1059" height="583" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>The most important thing to look out for <b>complete: true</b> – this is the gold you want to see and means the process has worked. The money is <i>nearly</i> yours.</li>
<li>Finally, you need to broadcast the shiny signed transaction to the Bitcoin network. Copy all the black text (outlined in the red box in the screen shot in the previous step) to your clipboard, navigate back down to the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrefund-stage2">Transaction String Formatting – REFUND Stage 2</a> and paste the text in and click <b>[Generate Refund Broadcast Transaction Command]</b>.</li>
<li>Copy the purple text to your clipboard, paste it into the Bitcoin-QT Debug window and hit <b>[Enter]</b> on your keyboard.</li>
<li>You’re done. The return from the <b>sendrawtransaction</b> command will be a transaction ID you can use to monitor the progress of the transaction on the Bitcoin network:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/79.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3323" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/79.png" alt="79" width="1059" height="583" /> </a> The very last step is to return to <b>TMP</b> and click the <b>[Mark as Claimed]</b> button. This just removes the refund from your list so <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><b>don’t [Mark as Claimed] until you’ve confirmed your Bitcoins have been successfully refunded</b></span>. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/80.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3324" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/80.png" alt="80" width="997" height="731" /> </a></p>
<p>This section covers the setup of your shop and the creation and sale of your first product. The great thing at <b>TMP</b> is that you can configure your store-front and sell yourself one of your products without having to actually obtain full permission from <b>TMP</b> staff to offer products. No one else will be able to buy your products until you are approved, but it does provide a great way to test the process end-to-end without relying on some third party to buy something. The product that we will be creating will be a test. <b>Note:</b> that you will pay a service fee for every completed order to <b>TMP</b>, even if you’ve sold to yourself. So we’ll be using the minimum values possible to reduce your exposure but the process won’t be free. Log in to your <b>TMP</b> account and select the <b>[Become a vendor]</b> menu option on the left hand side: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/81.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3325" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/81.png" alt="81" width="931" height="443" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Review the Security Policy and Vendor Agreement. Once you are satisfied, select <b>[Continue]</b> from Vendor Agreement screen.</li>
<li>In the <b>Vendor Creation: Shop Settings</b> window provide the name of your shop and an appropriate tag line. Leave the <b>Public</b> checkbox unchecked for now (You will need to change this when you’re account is approved and you want buyers to be able to see your shop). Once you’re happy, click <b>[Next]</b></li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/82.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3326" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/82.png" alt="82" width="974" height="419" /> </a></p>
<p>In the <b>Vendor Creation: Profile</b> window, provide some information about yourself, your terms and conditions etc and click <b>[Next]</b> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/83.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3327" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/83.png" alt="83" width="978" height="459" /> </a></p>
<p>In the final agreement window, click <b>[Finish]</b> and your shop will be created. You will now notice that a <b>Shop Management</b> icon has appeared across the top of your menu. Click this to navigate to the shop interface. <b>Note:</b> To approve your shop so that you can receive real orders, you will need to contact the individual listed. This is not necessary for the purposes of this test shop, but remember; until approved your shop is only visible to you. <a href="/imgs/2014/01/84.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3328" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/84.png" alt="84" width="952" height="403" /> </a></p>
<p>The <b>Shop Management</b> interface gives you an overview of your orders, allows you to manage products, shipping options, orders and – most important – retrieve Bitcoins stored in <b>Bitcoin Deposit Addresses</b> from completed orders. The screen has been annotated below: <a href="/imgs/2014/01/85.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3329" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/85.png" alt="85" width="1294" height="438" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Lets start by dealing with the most complicated part; creating the keys (read: “wallets” in <b>TMP</b> terminology) you need for orders that you will receive. Click the <b>[Wallets]</b> link on the left hand side and the</li>
<li id="selling-s8">every-time a buyer wants to pay you for an order, <b>TMP</b> forms a <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> from one of your keys, a key it generates internally behind the scenes, and a key provided by the buyer (See steps 23-to-27 of the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#installation">installation</a> section of this guide for a recap of this process from the buyers perspective).</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/86.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3330" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/86.png" alt="86" width="982" height="271" /> </a></p>
<p>As a seller, you therefore need a large stock of keys that can be used by <b>TMP</b> and your buyers to generate a unique <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. For every <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> created, one of your keys is consumed. Annoyingly this can mean that buyers can enter their key, TMP generates the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> using one of yours, one of its own and the buyers key, but then the buyer doesn’t pay and you’re down a key. It is therefore important to remember that the <b>signing wallet count</b> (See Step 6 screenshot) is not reflective of the number of orders you will have. Unpaid orders will never be seen by you – they just cost you a key.</p>
<p>Since a key (read: “wallet”) is just a repurposed Bitcoin Address, there are a number of ways to generate them. One of the easiest way to create a bulk lot of Bitcoin Addresses is using the Bitcoind.exe that comes with Bitcoin-QT (see <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#prerequisites">prerequisites</a> for links). This is a great way to do it because bitcoind then takes care of storing your Bitcoin Addresses (your keys) securely in its own wallet.dat and you can also easily access the private part of each ‘key’ that you need when you come to claim your Bitcoins from completed orders. You’re basically using Bitcoin-QT as a vault to store all your order keys. A guide on this will be covered elsewhere.</p>
<p><b>Note:</b> Bitcoin-QT does not need to be connected to the internet, you can create your Bitcoin Addresses you will use as keys completely offline – the magic of Bitcoin math.</p>
<p>The second, simplest but more manually intensive way is to use a Bitcoin Address generator website. Because this is a simple guide to get you into the swing of things, that’s what we’re going to use.</p>
<ol>
<li id="selling-s9">In a separate browser window, navigate to <a href="https://www.bitaddress.org/">https://www.bitaddress.org/</a>. Move your mouse around (if prompted) to begin the initial Bitcoin Address generation process. Once it has returned a Bitcoin Address, open <b>Notepad</b> or your favourite text editor (or you can use Excel). Add three columns; “Bitcoin Address”, “Private Key” and “Public Key (130 Chars)” and copy the Bitcoin Address and Private Key into the Notepad file. Leave the Public Key column blank, we’ll populate that presently. Repeat this process to generate two addresses, the resultant <b>Notepad</b> file should look like:<a href="/imgs/2014/01/87.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3342" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/87.png" alt="87" width="1036" height="443" /> </a></li>
<li id="selling-s10">Click the <b>Wallet Details</b> tab and enter the Private Key from one of the addresses in your <b>Notepad</b> file. Click <b>[View Details]</b> to display all the information about the Bitcoin Address. Highlight the <b>Public Key (130 characters [0-9A-F]):</b> value and paste it alongside the appropriate Bitcoin Address in your <b>Notepad</b> file. Repeat for the second address. The result should look like this:<a href="/imgs/2014/01/88.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3343" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/88.png" alt="88" width="1034" height="418" /> </a></li>
<li>You’ve now generated two order keys! This means that <b>TMP</b> can create two <b>Bitcoin Deposit Addresses</b> and – if your customer pays – you would have two orders. Return to <b>TMP</b> <b>Wallets</b> screen and click the <b>Add Wallets</b> button to add your newly generated keys.<b>Note:</b> Ensure you save the <b>Notepad</b> file somewhere safe. You will need the Private Key against each Bitcoin Address (key) to retrieve the Bitcoins associated with that order.</li>
<li>In this window, you can bulk add a massive amount of keys. For the purposes of this demonstration, we’re just going to add the two we created. The window helpfully tells you how you should format your keys: <b>Bitcoin-Address</b> <b>Bitcoin-Address-Public-Key</b>. Paste the appropriate strings from your <b>Notepad</b> file in to this window, pressing <b>[Enter]</b> to place each key on a new line. The result should look like this:<a href="/imgs/2014/01/88.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3343" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/88.png" alt="88" width="1034" height="418" /> </a>Once you’re done, click the <b>[Add Wallets]</b> button to store your keys in your account.</li>
<li>The screen will now return you to the “Wallets” overview. You will see your shiny new keys have been added, and the adjacent (X) allows you to see if it’s been used to generate a <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> yet. Since you have no orders, this will just show an <b>X</b> against both keys. Remember: Your “wallets” (read: keys) can only be used once; Basically <b>One key to one order (even if unpaid)</b>.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/89.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3344" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/89.png" alt="89" width="980" height="593" /> </a></li>
<li>Once you’re done, click the <b>[Add Wallets]</b> button to store your keys in your account.</li>
<li>The screen will now return you to the “Wallets” overview. You will see your shiny new keys have been added, and the adjacent (X) allows you to see if it’s been used to generate a <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> yet. Since you have no orders, this will just show an <b>X</b> against both keys. Remember: Your “wallets” (read: keys) can only be used once; Basically <b>One key to one order (even if unpaid)</b>.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/90.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3345" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/90.png" alt="90" width="992" height="414" /> </a></li>
<li>You’re now good to create a product and sell it to yourself (excited?). First up, you need to define a Shipping Option. Click the <b>Shipping Options</b> link from the menu on the left hand side. Once the dialog appears, click the <b>[Add]</b> button in the top right to define a new option. Fill in some details and click <b>[Create]</b>.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/911.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3349" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/911.png" alt="91" width="979" height="367" /> </a>You’ll be returned to the <b>Shipping Options</b> screen where your available options will be summarised.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/921.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3350" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/921.png" alt="92" width="977" height="316" /> </a></li>
<li>The next stage is to create a product to sell to yourself. Click the <b>Products</b> link from the menu on the left-hand side. The <b>Products</b> summary screen will be displayed.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/931.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3351" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/931.png" alt="93" width="980" height="218" /> </a></li>
<li>Click the <b>[Add]</b> button to begin the Product creation process.Create your product along the lines demonstrated in the screenshot below. Ensure the <b>Visible</b> box is <b>not</b> checked (You don’t want to show the test product if you’ve asked for your account to be approved) and also ensure you minimize the cost of your product to the lowest amount possible (Just incase things go wrong).<a href="/imgs/2014/01/94.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3352" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/94.png" alt="94" width="982" height="1630" /> </a></li>
<li>When you’re happy, click <b>[Create]</b> to add the product to your inventory.Once the product has been added, you’ll receive notification across the top bar and the page will redisplay your product in ‘update’ mode. Also a new button will appear; <b>[View on site]</b>. The <b>[view on site]</b> button allows you to preview your product as your buyers would. It also allows you to purchase the product yourself, allowing you to test the order process.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/95.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3353" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/95.png" alt="95" width="1274" height="306" /> </a>Click the <b>View on site</b>. This will open a new tab showing your product. Select a Shipping Option and choose <b>[Add to Cart]</b><a href="/imgs/2014/01/96.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3354" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/96.png" alt="96" width="995" height="399" /> </a>The product will now be added to your cart and you’ll be able to preview the process as any buyer would. In order to save space, navigate back up this guide and follow <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#checkout">Steps 21 to 35 inclusive</a> of the buyers guide. Once you’ve done that, return here and click the <b>Shop Management</b> link to return to the shop management overview screen.</li>
<li>As soon as the payment for the recently created order has cleared (reached 6 confirmations), your management view will show the order in the <b>New Orders</b> sub-window. Go ahead and click <b>[View]</b> next to the order:</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/97.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3355" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/97.png" alt="97" width="972" height="348" /> </a></li>
<li>You now be presented with the order summary screen. Shipping information, payment and product information is summarised here. You also now have the option of either accepting or rejecting the order. Click <b>[Approve]</b><a href="/imgs/2014/01/98.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3356" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/98.png" alt="98" width="969" height="766" /> </a></li>
<li>Now you have accepted the order, your view will change to allow you to migrate the order to the final state of fulfilment: Shipped. At this point, you can either click <b>Mark As Shipped</b> or leap back to the <b>Orders</b> overview so you can see how the various sub-windows have updated. Once you are happy, return to the order and click <b>[Mark As Shipped]</b>:<a href="/imgs/2014/01/99.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3357" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/99.png" alt="99" width="1032" height="256" /> </a></li>
<li>Finally, once you have shipped the order, it will migrate to <b>Shipped Orders</b> sub-window. Shipped orders are ones which require no further interaction from you. At this point, the buyer needs to <b>Finalize</b> the transaction to indicate the goods have been received and you can move on to the final stage and claim your Bitcoins.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/100.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3358" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/100.png" alt="100" width="977" height="518" /> </a></li>
<li>As you are the buyer in this transaction, you need to return to the buyers view so you can <b>Finalize</b> the order. To do this, click on your account name and select <b>Account</b> from the menu. From the left hand-menu, under the <b>Orders</b> heading, click <b>[List]</b>.</li>
<li>When the order details screen comes up, click the <b>Finalize order</b> button. Leave yourself a nice review, you deserve it. Once you are done, return to the <b>Shop Management</b> interface.</li>
<li>Before you can collect payment, you need to make sure you have nominated a Bitcoin Address that <b>TMP</b> will use to generate the transaction that releases the Bitcoins from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> to you. To do this click the <b>Settings</b> link from the menu and the <b>Vendor Settings</b> window will be displayed:</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/101.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3359" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/101.png" alt="101" width="970" height="657" /> </a></li>
<li>Enter the Bitcoin Address that you want to use to receive the Bitcoins retrieved from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. This could be an exchange deposit address, a blockchain.info wallet address a paper wallet – anywhere you like. Just make sure it’s one you own. When you are done click <b>[Save]</b>.Finally, lets retrieve payment. From the menu on the left-hand side, select <b>[Payments]</b> to bring up the payments window. This shows all the payments (remember it’s one payment per order) that are waiting for you. Click the <b>[Sign]</b> button against the payment.<a href="/imgs/2014/01/102.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3360" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/102.png" alt="102" width="1075" height="304" /> </a></li>
<li>You are now presented with the signing window – DONT PANIC! It looks complicated, but its pretty straightforward once you get the hang of it.As indicated in the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#concepts">Concepts</a> part of this guide, this is basically the transaction that has been created and signed by <b>TMP</b> and now just needs your signature to release the funds to you. There are two commands shown in this window, the first is <b>signrawtransaction</b> which when run, is basically you signing on the dotted line and giving authorisation to move the Bitcoins from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> used for the order to your nominated Bitcoin Address. The transaction also includes <b>TMP’s</b> service fee which is sent to a Bitcoin Address they choose. You can actually decode the transaction to see what’s going to go where by pasting the highlighted text into <a href="https://blockchain.info/decode-tx">https://blockchain.info/decode-tx</a>:<a href="/imgs/2014/01/103.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone  wp-image-3361" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/103.png" alt="103" width="997" height="734" /> </a></li>
<li>and this is what you should see on <a href="https://blockchain.info">blockchain.info</a> (Remember to only visit in TOR Browser – just to ensure your privacy)<a href="/imgs/2014/01/104.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3362" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/104.png" alt="104" width="1203" height="654" /> </a></li>
<li>
<ol>
<li>The second command is <b>sendrawtransaction</b> and all this does is broadcast the transaction you signed to the Bitcoin network (need a Bitcoin-QT client with an internet connection for this). Only then can the actual Bitcoin transfer take place (remember; Bitcoin is a big distributed ledger, it has to <i>know</i> about it, or it didn’t happen).Now that you (hopefully) understand the commands you are going to run – you need to run them. To be able to that we are now going to switch back to Bitcoin-QT which you’ve hopefully got running.</li>
<li>To run the commands open Bitcoin-QT, go to <b>Menu</b>-&gt;<b>Debug Window</b> and click the <b>Console</b> tab. The view should look like this:</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/105.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3363" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/105.png" alt="105" width="756" height="488" /> </a></li>
<li>Open the <b>Notepad</b> file you created back in stage 10, and copy the Private Key associated with the Bitcoin Address indicated in the <b>TMP</b> Transaction window to your clipboard (highlighted in blue below):</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/106.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3364" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/106.png" alt="106" width="1188" height="278" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>You now need to insert the private key in place of the text marked <b>PRIVATEKEYHERE</b> in the string and then copy everything from the word <b>signrawtransaction</b> to your clipboard and paste the result into the Bitcoin-QT debug window. Mercifully, there are some quick and dirty string formatting tools to do most of the work for you at the base of this guide under the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransaction-paymentretrieval">Transaction String Formatting – Payment Retrieval</a> heading.</li>
<li>Paste your private key that’s (hopefully) still on your clipboard in the <b>Private Key</b> box and all the text from the <b>signrawtransaction</b> box into the <b>Transaction text</b> box and press <b>[Format Transaction]</b>.</li>
<li>Now copy all the blue text onto your clipboard and return to the Bitcoin-QT debug window and paste it in and press <b>[Enter]</b>.</li>
<li>You should receive a result something like this in black text:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/107.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3365" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/107.png" alt="107" width="1059" height="583" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>The most important thing to look out for <b>complete: true</b> – this is the gold you want to see and means the process has worked. The money is <i>nearly</i> yours.</li>
<li>Finally, you need to broadcast the shiny signed transaction to the Bitcoin network. Copy all the black text (outlined in the red box in the screen shot in the previous step) to your clipboard, navigate back down to the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransaction">Transaction String Formatting</a> area <b>Stage 2</b> and paste the text in and click <b>[Generate Broadcast Transaction Command]</b>.</li>
<li>Copy the purple text to your clipboard, paste it into the Bitcoin-QT Debug window and hit <b>[Enter]</b> on your keyboard.</li>
<li>You’re done. The return from the <b>sendrawtransaction</b> command will be a transaction ID you can use to monitor the progress of the transaction on the Bitcoin network:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/108.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3366" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/108.png" alt="108" width="1059" height="583" /> </a></p>
<p>The very last step is to return to <b>TMP</b> and click the <b>[Mark as Claimed]</b> button. This just removes the transaction from your list so <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><b>don’t [Mark as Claimed] until you’ve confirmed your Bitcoins have been successfully redeemed</b></span>.</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/109.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3367" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/109.png" alt="109" width="1040" height="354" /> </a></p>
<p>A few final words. Don’t worry about re-running the claim commands a few times, when you broadcast the transaction (<b>sendrawtransaction</b>) the Bitcoin network will only recognise the first successful attempt, so any further tries won’t yield more Bitcoins, they’ll just be ignored.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>In this section we cover how to go about recovering Bitcoins from a <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> without using <b>TMP</b>. The purpose is to illustrate that, in the event of <b>TMP</b> collapsing, sellers and buyers can still complete outstanding <b>paid</b> orders lessening the financial impact on both the parties involved (buyer and seller). If you have not covered the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#concepts">Concepts</a> section of this guide, take a moment to recap before continuing. Since this tutorial is primarily aimed at sellers, we’re going to be selling ourselves a product (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling">Selling on The Marketplace</a> section). This makes it easy to ensure we’ve got access to the necessary keys required to unlock the Bitcoins in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> for the order we’re going to create.</p>
<p>Before beginning, there are a few things that – sellers especially – should be aware of. In order to recover any of the Bitcoins that reside in an order <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, both the seller and the buyer have to be able to contact each other. This is necessary because either the buyer or the seller is going to need to fill the shoes of <b>TMP</b> and create and sign a transaction (insert their key) that will then be provided to the counter-party to also sign-off on (insert their key) and broadcast the result to the Bitcoin network so the Bitcoins can be released from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. Since a buyer and a seller do not ever come into direct contact with each-other through <b>TMP</b> except when using <b>TMP’s</b> messaging system (remember; orders a seller receives are never explicitly tied to a <b>TMP</b> buyer’s account), establishing communication channels can be the trickiest part.</p>
<p>As a general rule of thumb, buyers who have paid for an order but who have not had their order accepted by a seller at the time of <b>TMP’s</b> closure or have not yet received a shipped order, are going to be more inclined to make the effort to get in contact with the seller. Buyers who have received their order but had not <b>Finalized</b> it at the time of <b>TMP’s</b> closure are significantly less likely to make the effort to help the seller recover any Bitcoins trapped in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> for the particular order. The buyer won’t be able to recover the Bitcoins either, so there is no financial gain – it just means that the Bitcoins will remain trapped in eternity until either <b>TMP</b> recovers, or the two parties (buyer and seller) can get in contact and come to an agreement.</p>
<p>To summarise; as a seller do not assume you will be able to recover all outstanding funds owed to you for shipped orders. You should be able to recover something though, and something is better than nothing. It’s also 100% more than traditional trust based darknet markets (E.g. Pandora, SilkRoad2, BlueSky etc).</p>
<p><b>Note:</b> If <b>TMP</b> subsequently returns after an outage, a seller can set about reclaiming any Bitcoins in outstanding orders where the buyer was uncontactable, using the platforms built in mechanisms (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling">Steps 23-to-34 in the Sellers section</a>) and a buyer can set about recovering Bitcoins from any <b>Unapproved</b> order through the refund mechanism (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#refunds">All steps in the Order Refunds section</a>). It may be a bit of an auditing headache to reconcile everything; remove orders that have been claimed outside <b>TMP</b> and claim orders that haven’t, but that’s it. Because the Bitcoins for each paid order are sitting in their <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> it’s just a matter of claiming them. A seller doesn’t have to trust <b>TMP</b> to have a wallet filled with Bitcoins to back an ephemeral website balance (Think: Sheep Market and the Bitcoin withdrawal issues suffered near its end when someone had run away with all the money).</p>
<p>How a seller and their buyers get in contact with each-other is a matter of personal choice. It could be as simple as including a contact email address on the vendor profile, posting a PGP encrypted message (encrypted with the public PGP key of the recipient) on a high-traffic social platform such as Reddit, or through a more secure durable communication platform such Bitmessage combined with TOR (recommended approach).</p>
<p><b>Note:</b> The use of Bitmessage is not covered in this tutorial. Links to a simple tutorial are provided in the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#prerequisites">Prerequisites section</a> of this guide.</p>
<p>Let’s begin…</p>
<p>Place an order with yourself by following <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling">Steps 8 to 18 inclusive of the Sellers</a> section. Click the <b>[Shop Management]</b> link on the top menu-bar to view your shops overview. You should see your recently <b>paid</b> order sitting in the <b>New Orders</b> sub-window:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/109.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3367" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/109.png" alt="109" width="1040" height="354" /> </a> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/110.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3368" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/110.png" alt="110" width="987" height="357" /> </a></p>
<p>Click the <b>[View]</b> button adjacent to order to bring up the order detail screen. When this displays, click the <b>[Show Payment Information]</b> button along the top:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/1111.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3369" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/1111.png" alt="111" width="990" height="384" /> </a></p>
<p>to display the payment information associated with this order:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/112.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3370" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/112.png" alt="112" width="1198" height="960" /> </a></p>
<p>Now that you hopefully have a better understanding of the information shown on the <b>Payment Information</b> screen, you will want to know which bits are actually relevant to make you able to retrieve the Bitcoins outside of <b>TMP</b>. The only pieces of information you need from this screen are:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <b>Redeem Script</b>; and</li>
<li>The <b>Escrow Wallet</b> (This is the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>); and</li>
<li>The <b>Transaction ID</b>; and</li>
<li>The <b>Sellers Public Key</b></li>
</ul>
<p>You might be wondering why you don’t need the other ‘Public’ keys? You don’t need them because – as the seller – you already have the ‘Private’ part of your key to the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, which you recorded in your <b>Notepad</b> file in <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling-s8">Steps 8, 9 and 10 of the Sellers section</a>. The ‘Private’ part of your <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> key is effectively the <i>real</i> key, while the ‘Public’ part is the equivalent of being able to tell the world that you have ownership of the ‘Private’ part but doesn’t allow anyone who has it to use it to move Bitcoins out of the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. ‘Private’ trumps ‘Public’.</p>
<p>You are recording the sellers public key because it will make it easier for you to track down the correct Private Key to use to sign-off the transaction. If you’ve got 1000′s of keys – all for different orders – it would be a management nightmare trying to work out which Private Key you needed to use to unlock the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. Recording it here means you can just search the <b>Notepad</b> file you created <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling-s10">Step 10 of the Sellers section</a> (or whatever storage method you’ve chosen to use).</p>
<p><b>Note:</b> Because you are also acting as the buyer in this tutorial, you will also have access to the buyers Private key which you recorded in <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#buyerkey">Steps 24 and 25 of the Buyers section</a> when you placed your order. In normal circumstances you would not have access to this and so once you created and signed the transaction (inserted your key), you would pass the signed transaction to the buyer for them to also sign-off (insert their key) and broadcast the result to Bitcoin Network to release the Bitcoins from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. Don’t worry, this will all be covered in detail in the following steps.</p>
<p>Open <b>Notepad</b> or your favourite text editor, and create four columns: <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>, <b>Transaction ID</b>, <b>Redeem Script</b> and <b>Sellers Public Key</b>. Copy the values from the <b>Payment Information</b> screen. The result should look something like this:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/113.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3371" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/113.png" alt="113" width="1640" height="841" /> </a></p>
<p>You now have the information you – as the seller – need to create and sign (insert your key) the transaction. For the next part we’re going to be using a combination of <a href="https://blockchain.info/rawtx">https://blockchain.info/rawtx</a> (Visit in TOR) and the Bitcoin-QT Debug window. You can do <i>everything</i> in the Bitcoin-QT Debug window but by using <a href="https://blockchain.info">blockchain.info</a>, we minimize the chances of mistakes.</p>
<p>The Bitcoin commands we will be running are:</p>
<ul>
<li><b>createrawtransaction</b>: (Run by: Seller) – Creates the transaction that releases the Bitcoins from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> to the sellers chosen Bitcoin Address (a paper wallet, blockchain.info wallet or Bitcoin exchange – any Bitcoin Address the seller owns)</li>
<li><b>signrawtransaction</b>: (Run by: Seller <b>and</b> Buyer) – Two keys must be inserted to release the Bitcoins, so the first signatory (key insertion) will be from the seller. The seller will run this command (<b>signrawtransaction</b>) on the result from <b>createrawtransaction</b> in the step above. The output will then be passed to the buyer who will also run <b>signrawtransaction</b> to sign off (insert their key) and the final result can then be broadcast to the Bitcoin Network.</li>
<li><b>sendrawtransaction</b>: (Run by: Seller <b>or</b> Buyer) – Broadcasts the transaction that has been signed by both the seller <i>and</i> buyer to the Bitcoin Network so the Bitcoins are actually moved (Remember; the Bitcoin Network needs to <i>know</i> about it or it didn’t happen). The transaction that is broadcast must be the one that both the buyer and seller have signed off on. In this tutorial this will be when the buyer runs <b>signrawtransaction</b> (final key in the lock). If the seller wants to broadcast the transaction, they can ask the buyer to just send them the result of <b>signrawtransaction</b> and then they (the seller) can run <b>sendrawtransaction</b> themselves. The result of running this command successfully is the transaction ID, which can be plugged in to <a href="https://blockchain.info">blockchain.info</a> to check its progress on the Bitcoin Network (number of confirmations etc).</li>
</ul>
<p>To run the commands open Bitcoin-QT, go to Menu-&gt;Debug Window and click the Console tab. The view should look like this:</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/114.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3372" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/114.png" alt="114" width="756" height="488" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>To create the raw transaction, we need to know some information about the transaction that was used to deposit the Bitcoins into the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. Fortunately, <a href="https://blockchain.info">blockchain.info</a> stores this information in an easily accessible manner, but you need to go to a special URL to get it. You can reach it by manually putting <b>https://blockchain.info/rawtx/{REPLACE-ME-WITH-THE-TRANSACTION-ID-YOU-RECORDED-IN-THE-TEXT-FILE-IN-STEP-3}?scripts=true</b> into your address bar, but mercifully, tools exist under the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransaction-rawtx">Transaction String Formatting – Create My Own Raw Transaction</a> to guide you through the process (which is what we’ll use). The five stages are:
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage1">Stage 1. Generate *RAWTX* URL on blockchain.info</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage2">Stage 2. Generate *RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>createrawtransaction</i> command</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage3">Stage 3. Generate *SELLERS RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>signrawtransaction</i> command</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage4">Stage 4. Generate *BUYERS RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>signrawtransaction</i> command</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage5">Stage 5. Generate *BUYER OR SELLER RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>sendrawtransaction</i> command</a></li>
</ul>
<p>Click the link to <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage1">Stage 1</a> above, and paste the requested value into the boxes (The Transaction ID) to generate the <b>blockchain.info</b> link. Copy the link into your browser address bar (or click it) and copy all the text in the box highlighted onto your clipboard. Helpful screenshots by the stages tell you what text you need to copy where.</li>
<li>Progress to <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage2">Stage 2</a> and enter the information requested. You will source the <b>Transaction text</b> from <b>Stage 1</b> which you have just run, while the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> and <b>Redeem Script</b> will come from the details you noted down in <b>Step 3</b> from the <b>TMP</b> <b>Payment Information</b> screen. Once you have generated and run the <b>createrawtransaction</b> command, running it in Bitcoin-QT debug window should yield a long string in black text:</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/115.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3373" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/115.png" alt="115" width="1059" height="631" /> </a></li>
<li>Ensuring you leave all the boxes in <b>Stage 2</b> populated, move on to <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage3">Stage 3</a>. For this you will need the Private key that is associated with the repurposed Bitcoin Address that you have – as the seller – used as your key to the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. You should have this in a <b>Notepad</b> file which you made in <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#selling-s10">Step 10 of the Sellers section</a>. Search this file for the <b>sellers public key</b> you recorded back in <b>Step 3.</b> and enter the Private Key that is on the same row:</li>
</ol>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/116.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3374" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/116.png" alt="116" width="1165" height="525" /> </a></p>
<p>Once you’ve got the <i>signrawtransaction</i> command text back from half-way through <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage3">Stage 3</a>, run it in Bitcoin-QT Debug window. Notice that the result says <b>complete: false</b> (highlighted in green in the screenshot below). This means that only one signatory (you; the seller) has signed off (inserted their key). One more signatory is required (the buyer) before the Bitcoins in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> can be released.</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/116.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3374" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/116.png" alt="116" width="1165" height="525" /> </a> <a href="/imgs/2014/01/117.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3375" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/117.png" alt="117" width="1059" height="631" /> </a></p>
<p>Copy the resulting black text (everything inside the red box in the screenshot above) into the <b>Seller Signed Transaction Text</b> box <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#createtx-stage35">midway through <b>Stage 3</b></a> and click the <b>[Generate Transaction Signing Text For Buyer]</b>. At this stage, you would normally send the resulting text to the buyer who would then continue the process from <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage2">Stage 4</a>, but since you are also the buyer just paste the resulting output into the <b>Transaction Text provided to you by the Seller</b> box along with the buyers Private Key (You should have hopefully stored this when you paid for your order – see <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#buyerkey">Steps 24-to-27 in the Buyers Section</a> to recap).</p>
<p>Press the <b>[Generate Buyers Transaction Signing Command]</b> and run the resulting output in Bitcoin-QT Debug Window. If the process has worked, you will see <b>complete: true</b> (highlighted in green in the screenshot below) . This is the gold you are looking for. This means the transaction is ready to be broadcast to the Bitcoin Network. The money is nearly yours!</p>
<p><a href="/imgs/2014/01/118.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3376" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/118.png" alt="118" width="1059" height="631" /> </a></p>
<ol>
<li>Copy all the black text highlighted in the red box in the screenshot above to your clipboard and paste it in to the <b>Signed Transaction Text provided by the Buyer</b> box in <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage5">Stage 5</a>. Click the <b>[Generate Buyer-Seller Signed Broadcast Transaction Command]</b> to generate the final command.</li>
<li>Paste the result of <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#formattransactionrawtx-stage5">Stage 5</a> into your Bitcoin-QT Debug window and run it. If the process has worked, you’ll be returned a transaction ID and your Bitcoins should be winging their way to you.</li>
<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/119.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3377" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/119.png" alt="119" width="1057" height="631" /> </a></li>
<li>
<ol>
<li value="12">That’s it. You’re done. Really. You may wish to house-clean so you don’t have a now unusable order clogging up your list. You can do that by declining it in the <b>Shop Management</b> view, and then – as the buyer – navigating to your refunds screen and just putting a random Bitcoin address into the claim screen and hitting the <b>[Mark As Claimed]</b> button. For detailed overview of the Refund process, see the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#refunds">Refunds</a> section.</li>
</ol>
<p>A final cautionary note. Although (if you’re suitably masochistic) you might be thinking that you can circumvent <b>TMP’s</b> fees this way, you can – but they’ll find out. Remember, <b>TMP</b> is a key holder in every order, so it is trivial for them check paid <b>Bitcoin Deposit Addresses</b> and see which ones have had their funds spent without giving <b>TMP</b> their fee… repeat offenders (without mitigating circumstances) are likely to risk having their accounts closed. It’s in everyone’s interest to ensure everyone else gets their slice of the cake, so that buyers and sellers have somewhere safe, secure and reliable to conduct business on.</p>
<p>The default string that is provided when you want to claim a transaction does not work with the Windows Bitcoin Daemon. The reason is the escapement of quotes. This JavaScript will format the transaction into a block you can paste into a DOS box and get your signed transaction from.</p>

<h2 id="formattransaction-rawtx">Create My Own Raw Transaction</h2>
<p>These tools are used to create raw transactions for you. They are used in conjunction with the <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#whatif">Finalising transactions outside of The Marketplace</a> section of this guide.</p>

<li><a href="/imgs/2014/01/123.png" rel="lightbox"> <img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3381" src="https://www.deepdotweb.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/123.png" alt="123" width="428" height="339" /> </a></li>

<p>This stage depends on the values (Bitcoin Deposit Address, Redeem Script etc) that you have hopefully just entered in <b>Stage 2</b>. If not, complete <b>Stage 2</b> before moving on to this stage and don’t clear the boxes.</p>
<p>Paste the result of the <i>createrawtransaction</i> command from <b>Step 2</b> into the <b>Unsigned Transaction Text:</b> box below to sign the transaction as the Seller</p>
<p>Sellers Private Key: (Your key – as the seller – to the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>)</p>

<h3 id="formattransactionrawtx-stage4">Stage 4. Generate *BUYERS RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>signrawtransaction</i> command</h3>
<p>As the Buyer, you will need the Private Key from your repurposed Bitcoin Address that you stored when you created your order (See <a href="http://www.deepdotweb.com/2013/12/30/full-guide-how-to-access-i2p-sites-use-themarketplace-i2p#buyerkey">Steps 24-to-27 in the Buyers Section</a>) to sign the transaction the seller has sent you. This will enable you (or the seller) to release the Bitcoins stored in the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b> (See <b>Stage 5</b>).</p>
<p>The text you are pasting in should look something like this:</p>
<div>
<p>signrawtransaction 01000000014a4ba53608f7d2fb6f478d9e1f71c6f2f67de765</p>
<p>958430fcfa969bdad3d1af14730440220692fdee8d5dd7c2aa9109731f4eeeb</p>
<p>6ba751d7863b26a201000000f400539985aeb5a438a06bef976c5b6858b7a7</p>

<p>7a7aad8be912fb33737aa1017327af13a5d8bb721c65c5</p>
<p>861ba52368119941045d2e9b84c928de41495356d692ca91daa41f49d7464b5</p>
<p>7cdec1b9b63be3b36deb969bd4fbf1471ce4d794c165be</p>
<p>bf4aed59cce2a2ca2b223aed122102b63b8203f05249767712175200901db1c70</p>
<p>d836171df2fd05afeb016e42f3a2953aeffffffff01</p>
<p>f7bf1400000000001976a914c3e998b45efd5ccd99a560019103fc6bf83f5a50</p>
<p>88ac00000000 [{\&#8221;txid\&#8221;:\&#8221;de7c252a46a8cf</p>
<p>0f43585d751a76bf11a3d976da2263b86adc1ef70836a54b4a\&#8221;,\&#8221;vout\&#8221;:1,</p>
<p>\&#8221;scriptPubKey\&#8221;:\&#8221;a3d1014815899171c46a9ba3f</p>
<p>7445ce6b1bd4b05485187\&#8221;,\&#8221;redeemScript\&#8221;:\&#8221;7ec170d2963831ec34d95</p>

<p>Result (Paste this into your DOS command box or send it to the Seller):</p>

<h3 id="formattransactionrawtx-stage5">Stage 5. Generate *BUYER OR SELLER RAWTX* DOS bitcoind.exe compatible or Bitcoin-QT GUI Debug compatible <i>sendrawtransaction</i> command</h3>
<p>Paste the result of running the <i>signrawtransaction</i> text from <b>Step 4</b> above in Bitcoin-QT, into the box below to generate the command to tell the Bitcoin Network to move the Bitcoins from the <b>Bitcoin Deposit Address</b>. You should see the words <b>complete: true</b> in the text you paste in.</p>
